channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for AL
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for AL

item.title: Report E-2025030142
item.description:
Report E-2025030142

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-16T21:12:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-10
  • City: THEODORE
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On March 10, 2025, one (1) 3800-KG tote of nitric acid leaked approximately three (3) gallons to the trailer floor and gravel due to a faulty gasket. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from E3 to remediate the site. The crew utilized neutralizing absorbents and hand tools to remediate the site. All impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report I-2025020066
item.description:
Report I-2025020066

Identified by scraper @ 2025-03-16T21:12:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-02-04
  • City: CENTRE
  • State: AL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: OPEN WINDOWS LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While traveling, 3 - 275g totes fell from the trailer. Driver immediately pulled off road and local regulatory agencies were called to the scene. Marion Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon inspection, Marion Environmental determined all 3 fallen totes had been compromised and approximately 76 gallons had been released to roadside soil. Marion Environmental proceeded to transfer the remaining product from the damaged totes to 3 recovery totes, excavated the impacted soil along shoulder, and containerized damaged totes and soil within one dump truck, which was transported off site for disposal in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. All product was recovered, site was restored to preexisting condition, and no further action is planned. There were no injuries or exposures reported.
